title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #105 asks whether n-3 obstacle points can block all 'rich' lines through n non-collinear points. A rich line contains ≥2 points from the main set. The conjecture was DISPROVED by Xichuan with three explicit counterexamples. The $50 prize was awarded for the disproof.

title: Points in the Plane
content: We represent points as elements of EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2), which is the standard Mathlib type for ℝ². This gives us the full machinery of inner product spaces and affine geometry.

title: Line Representation
content: A line is represented parametrically: a base point plus t times a direction vector (where t ranges over ℝ). The direction must be nonzero. A point p lies on line L if p = basePoint + t·direction for some t.

title: Rich Lines
content: A line is 'rich' for a set A if it contains at least 2 distinct points from A. This is the key concept - we want to find rich lines that avoid obstacles.

title: Unblocked Lines
content: A line is 'unblocked' by a set B if it contains NO points of B. The goal is to find lines that are both rich (for A) and unblocked (by B).

title: Non-Collinearity
content: A set is non-collinear if no single line contains all its points. This is a crucial hypothesis - if all points were collinear, there would be exactly one rich line, making the problem trivial.

title: The Erdős-Purdy Conjecture
content: The conjecture states: for disjoint sets A (n points, non-collinear) and B (n-3 points), there must exist a rich line of A that avoids B entirely. This was the original hope - that n-3 obstacles aren't enough to block all rich lines.

title: Xichuan's Counterexample
content: Xichuan (2024) found three explicit counterexamples: configurations where A has n non-collinear points, B has n-3 points, yet EVERY rich line of A contains some point of B. This disproves the Erdős-Purdy conjecture.

title: The Formal Disproof
content: We prove ¬ErdosPurdyConjecture by contradiction: the conjecture would give a rich unblocked line for Xichuan's counterexample, but that example was constructed so NO such line exists. This is a clean formal argument using the axiom.

title: Hickerson's n-2 Construction
content: Before Xichuan, Hickerson showed that n-2 obstacles CAN block all rich lines. This meant n-3 was the 'critical case' - either the boundary of what's possible, or also achievable. Xichuan proved it's the latter.

title: Beck-Szemerédi-Trotter Positive Result
content: With only cn obstacles (c > 0 a small constant), some rich line MUST be unblocked. This uses the Szemerédi-Trotter incidence bound to show there are so many rich lines that cn obstacles can't block them all.

title: Szemerédi-Trotter Theorem
content: The famous Szemerédi-Trotter theorem (1983) bounds point-line incidences: I(P,L) = O(|P|^(2/3)|L|^(2/3) + |P| + |L|). This is optimal and fundamental to discrete geometry. It implies many rich lines exist.

title: The Threshold Function
content: f(n) = largest number such that f(n) obstacles can't block all rich lines of any n non-collinear points. Known: cn ≤ f(n) ≤ n-4. The exact value remains open.

title: Open Problem: n-4 Obstacles
content: Xichuan disproved n-3, and Hickerson disproved n-2. But what about n-4? Does the conjecture hold there? This is the natural next question after Xichuan's result.

title: Summary
content: Erdős Problem #105 is DISPROVED. The Erdős-Purdy conjecture (n-3 obstacles can't block all rich lines) is false. Key insight: while Szemerédi-Trotter guarantees many rich lines, carefully placed obstacles can block ALL of them.

title: Historical Timeline
content: 1983: Beck and Szemerédi-Trotter prove positive results with cn obstacles. 1995: Erdős-Purdy conjecture n-3. Later: Hickerson shows n-2 fails. 2024: Xichuan disproves n-3 with three counterexamples. The $50 prize was awarded.
